(an order to the crew) Main battery at ready! Davy Jones points his claw --
Fire! 649 CANNON FIRE THUNDERS as the two ships battle across t ON THE PEARL, two crewman race the length of the deck as cannonballs scream past, shot ends on Barbossa, who laugh
Hah! It be too late to alter course now, Mateys!
The Jacks are rocked by cannon fire. Jack is in action tearing out the bench, levering it against the brig door
-- Think like the whelp Think like the whelp Think like the whelp --  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 109.
Half-barrel hinges! Never work
Leverage! Jack shoves down on the bench; the brig door falls open.
Wish us luck, boys. We might need it. He moves past the bars. The Jacks watch him go.
I miss him already.
He'll be back.
(the Jacks turn) Dropped my brain.
Mercer is flanked by two GUARDS, Jones at his side.
Rake 'em! Keep up the barrage! Prepare to board! A CANNONBALL whistles toward them --

And keep your head about you. Jones pushes Mercer aside as the cannon ball crashes and takes out the two guards. Mercer looks gratefully at Jones; the look turns to horro as Jones' tentacle beard wraps around Mercer's neck Mercer chokes; MOVE AROUND to show Jones' face as Mercer' neck snaps. Mercer falls to the ground -- Held up briefly by the chain, with the key, held by Jones beard -- The chain snaps and Mercer falls.
Jack enters on a titled deck. Murtogg and Mullroy, very twitchy, swing the cannons toward him.  653 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 110.
Halt there, or we'll shoot! Jack stops.
Good one. I just came to see my effects. Admirable though it is why are you here when you could be somewhere else?
Someone has to stay and guard the chest.
No question, there's been a breakdown in military discipline aboard this vessel.
I blame the fish people.
Oh, so fish people, by dint of being fish people, automatically aren't as disciplined as non-fish people?
Seems contributory, is all I'm suggesting. Jack, meanwhile, has approached the chest and now he pick it up and sneaks off as they are arguing.
It is true that if there are no fish people there would be no reason to guard the chest.
If there were no chest, there would be nothing to guard. At that moment they both look down to see the chest is go

Jack Sparrow appears from the Captain's cabin, carrying t Chest. He circles around, stops -- -- ahead of him is Jones, coming down the steps. Jack see Jones has the key -- Jones sees Jack has the chest.  654 655 656 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 111.
Lookee, boys! A lost bird. A lost bird that never learned to fly! Crewman laugh and surge forward.
(looking for an escape route) To my great regret. (a-ha! found one!) But it's never too late, he? Jack sheathes his sword, tips his hat --
And now, anon, adieu. Grabs a sail, loosens the bottom tie. The sail, partially free, fills with wind, and carries Jack to the upper rigg
Jack lands, impressed with himself. Inches along, looks u and suddenly Jones is there. He draws his sword.
The chest. Hand it over. Jack draws his own sword.
I can set you free, Jones.
Have you never loved, Jack? My freedom was forfeit long ago. Jones leaps at Jack, swords clashing --
The two ships are drawn closer in an ever-tightening circ The giant masts of the two ships tilt toward -- close eno for attackers to swing on ropes, cross from ship to ship
Cannon fire BLASTS the Pearl. SOLDIERS from the Flying Dutchman swarm across, attack Will and Elizabeth. will ta advantage of a short break in the action (near capstan)

Elizabeth! Dying for something, that's the easy part. What are we going to live for?  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 112. Elizabeth gives him a "you've got to be kidding" look, an then more attackers are upon them.
Right now is not the best time! They fight around opposite sides of the capstan, come together:
(with a chuckle in his voice) Right now may be the only time! I love you! They are separated again, and then Will catches her hand:
I've made my choice. What's yours? Her eyes never leave his; she decides:
Barbossa! Will's a bit surprised at that answer but then it becomes clear, even as attackers separate them again:
Marry us! On the deck above, Barbossa fights off several Crewmen.
I'm a little busy at the moment. Elizabeth and Will fight on opposite sides of the deck:
Barbossa! Now!
Fine, then! He climbs atop the binnacle cabinet as they come back tog now's the time to begin the ceremony.
Dearly beloved and others, we are gathered here -- He's beset by attackers; so are they. As they fight down length of the deck, Will figures, screw it:  657 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 113.
Elizabeth Swann, do you take me to be your husband?
I do.
Great!
Will Turner, do you take me to be your wife? In sickness and health? With health being the less likely?
I do. On the wheel deck, Barbossa still wants his big moment:

As Captain, I pronounce you ... (more attackers) You may kiss -- kiss the -- just kiss! Will catches Elizabeth, they nearly kiss -- but then they are separated again. They fight their way back together -
Destiny.

head_text.subj: THE SOUNDS OF BATTLE RETURN. A LOUD EXPLOSION --

text: Jack and Jones spar. Jack strips Jones' sword from his gr
There is nothing you can do with that, without the key.
I already have the key. For a moment, Jones almost believes him, but then smiles display the key at the end of a tentacle.
No, you don't. Jones displays the key at the end of a tentacle on his be  658 659 660 661 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 114.

Oh, that key. With his half sword, Jack slices at Jones' tentacles. BLA INK sprays everywhere. The key falls -- -- lands on the deck of the Dutchman amid the splatter. S clutched by a writhing tentacle fragment. Livid, Jones shoves Jack backwards -- Jack slashes down - his sword is STOPPED by Jones' claw. Jones squeezes and J sword is snapped in half.
Cotton struggles with the wheel of the Black Pearl -- -- justs as the MASTS of the two ships SLAM TOGETHER --
The mast shakes and Jack loses his balance, the chest fal Jones screams --
-- he reaches down, saves the chest with his tentacle arm And dangling below, hanging on the chest -- is Jack

Will pulls his sword out of a crewman and turns, sees Jac situation, sees him hanging -- -- just as Murtogg and Mullroy swing across, slam into th ship. They crawl up over the railing -- -- and Will takes their rope, coils it around his arm --
Davy Jones slings Jack up and into the air -- Jack grabs onto a line -- Jack smashes into a Dutchman Crewman swinging on a line . Jack glances down, notices something --

Hullo, that's mine! Jack grabs the pistol from the Crewman as he head-butts h off the line. Jack comes swinging back around behind Jone FIRES the pistol --  662 663 664 665 666 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 115. Jones is hit; the chest, fall from his grip -- -- the chest SMASHING down on Haddrass as he tries to sit up; his entire head is forced down into his body. The che tumbles free -- -- just as Will lands on the deck, arrived from the Pearl He bends to pick up the chest, moves away --

Jones strides along the deck, moves through the fighting. REDCOAT stoops to pick up Jones' sword, examine it. Jones takes it from him and runs him through, never slowing -- Will glances over his shoulder, then back ahead -- where Maacus is right in front of him, blocking the way.

On Pintel and Ragetti, smirking, standing on either side a cannon ... they're up to something. REVEAL Jack-the-Mon crouched inside the barrel. Pintel lights the fuse -- -- KABOOM! -- the Monkey SHRIEKS in GLEE --
-- SMACK! Jack-the-Monkey slams into Maacus; he tears at tries to get it off his face --
Jack continues to swing around, looks down, sees --
Will moves past -- then is suddenly floored by -- Bootstrap Bill. The chest slides away. Will stands, has o a second to recognize his father --
It's me -- -- before Bootstrap slashes at him with his sword.

Stop! It's Will! Your son -- Will is forced to defend himself, but also not harm his f leaving the chest momentarily free -- Jones arrives at the chest -- 662 663 664 665 666  667 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 116. Jack drops down in front of Jones, pulls his sword -- too small from having been cut in half --

(he lets out a whimper at the sword) Jack looks, pulls a_ bayline pin out of the capstan, uses that to block Jones' attack -- Jack dodges, keeping the capstan between them. Jones goes straight through the capstan -- Jack spins the capstan turning Jones around to come out the other side -- As Will battles Bootstrap, giving ground --
Pintel, Ragetti and Gibbs arrive on deck -- -- as Barbossa fights with the wheel, straining to keep t two ships apart. He yells down --
The masts be tangled! The Dutchman is going down, and us with it! Gibbs cranes his neck, stares at the masts, turning --

Loose a cannon! Use chain shot -- blast us free! Pintel and Ragetti confront CLACKER. Clacker goes over th edge, leaving Pintel holding the iron balls, clinking together. Realization, he raises them --
We've got balls! Elizabeth rushes past --
Free the sails! Target the mast! She crouches, slashes at the cannon tie-down rope. Gibbs crouches down next to her --
I've got it -- go! He looks over toward the Dutchman -- Elizabeth follows hi gaze -- she sees --  668 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 117.

Jack races away -- but Jones leaps in front of him, block him. Jack retreats, but Jones slashes him across the face Jack lands hard on the deck Jones laughs, turns, and strides toward the chest -- And Elizabeth swings in, drops down in front of the chest
Harridan! You'll see no mercy from me!

(raises her sword) That's why I brought this. Jones sneers and attacks. Will looks over -- sees Elizabe is jeopardy. Jones wades in, beats Elizabeth backwards -- Will slashes at Bootstrap, disarms him. Grabs Bootstrap, slams him into the rail. Will pulls out his knife ... raises it. Looks like he is going to stab him --

I will not kill you. I made you a promise. Will slams the knife down -- into the railing, through Bootstrap's jacket, pinning him there. Turns away -- Bootstrap looks down, stares at the knife. It looks famil He tries to remember Jack rolls over on deck: right in front of his eyes is th tentacle crawling past him, headed back to its master -- dragging the key. Jack grabs it, worms the tentacle away looks over. The chest is sitting right there. Jack smiles. Jones backhands Elizabeth with his claw -- and suddenly a sword appears -- right through his chest. Davy Jones look over his shoulder -- Will is behind him. Jones looks down

Missed. Did you forget? I ama heartless wretch.  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 118. Jones bends the sword tip, locking it in place -- then wrenches sideways, freeing the sword from Will, knocking Will to the deck. Will's eyes shift toward Elizabeth. Jones looks from Will Elizabeth -- processes their relationship.
Ah. Love. A dreadful bond. Will backs away -- he has no weapon -- he is helpless. Jo pulls the sword through his body, tosses it aside.
Yet so easily severed. Tell me, William Turner. Jones raises his own sword.
Do you fear death? Suddenly Jones cries out. Looks over --

Do you? Jack stands with the chest open, and Jones still-beating heart in his hand. He squeezes it -- and Jones staggers, clutches at his chest. Jack smiles. He's got it all under control. Finally. Jones regains his balance ... takes stock of the situatio
It's a heady tonic ... (tosses the heart in his hand) . holding life and death in the palm of your hand.
You are a cruel man, Jack Sparrow. Self-serving and dishonest.
Self-serving and dishonest I'll give you, but cruel is a matter of perspective, is it not?

Is it? DAVY JONES STABS WILL TURNER. With Norrington's sword.  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 119. Elizabeth cries out -- Will, lying on deck, looks up -- he has been run through the very sword that he himself forged. Jack stands there with his cut-off sword, hesitates. Elizabeth races toward Will. Cradles him in her arms. ON BOOTSTRAP, as he sees Elizabeth. An expression of curi across his face -- and then, wonder -- And recognition. Bootstrap remembers.
William. My son. Jones turns toward Jack.

Take what you want most, Jack. Live forever -- Bootstrap races across the deck, lays into Jones. Attacks with rage. Jones is driven aside, overcome, to the railin of the ship. The two men grapple -- Jack looks at Will, mortally wounded. Will stares at the sword sticking out of him, looks up -- Jack glances across the abyss -- Barbossa at the wheel of the Pearl. The ships spin. The p of no return. Pintel and Ragetti, aim their cannon -- Jack looks at the heart. Raises his eyes to Will. To Elizabeth. Elizabeth looks to Jack, pleading --
Please. AT THE RAIL, Jones twists and gains the upper hand, forci Bootstrap out over the railing --

You will not forestall my judgment -- Suddenly Jones claws at his chest, cries out in anguish - The ship SHUDDERS -- Jones lets go of Bootstrap, looks over --  669 670 671 672 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 120. CLOSE ON: Jones' heart has been stabbed. By Jack's shorte sword. And Will's hand is on the sword hilt. Will Turner has stabbed the heart of Davy Jones. Will stands over the slain heart. Dark ink, volumes of it spreads out onto the deck -- Jones falls onto the rail. He opens his eyes one last tim stares into the whirling abyss, accepts his fate ...

Calypso -- ! Davy Jones falls over the rail, plummets down into the se at one with Calypso at last. ON THE BLACK PEARL, Pintel and Ragetti shoot their cannon ON THE DUTCHMAN, part of the mast is blown away -- ON THE PEARL, Barbossa turns the wheel outwards, and the Pearl fights to get free --
The Flying Dutchman spins, following him down, enveloped darkness, the sky faint above --
Elizabeth holds Will in her arms. He appears as though he going to say something, but does not -- he dies.

Will... Bootstrap pulls the knife from the rail. He moves toward Will, as do the other crewmen ... Jack grabs Elizabeth, pulls her away from Will. She strug briefly, but the grief is overwhelming. Jack escorts her through the enclosing circle of crewmen. Jimmy Legs carri the open chest.
The Dutchman must have The Dutchman must have a a Captain. living heart ...

(murmur ) Part of the ship, part of the crew, part of the ship, part of the crew ... 669 670 671 672  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 121. Bootstrap kneels beside Will, pulls open his shirt, raise the knife -- Jack has gathered the ropes of a flapping sail -- FIRES a pistol shot to blast a knot away -- arm around Elizabeth they are lifted from the deck by the wind-fill sail --

Jack and Elizabeth rising up, staring down as Will's body obscured from sight by the crewmen. Jack looks at Elizabe who continues to watch the ship grow smaller Jack the Monkey has hitched a ride; even he looks mournfu
The Flying Dutchman vanishes into the whirlpool.
Jack and Elizabeth land in the ocean near the Black Pearl
Barbossa, Pintel and Ragetti watch in horror as the Dutch is pulled down, spinning, into the depths. Gibbs helps pull Elizabeth over the rail, and then Jack.
Thank heaven, Jack. The armada is still out there, the Endeavour is coming up hard starboard, and I think it's time we embraced that oldest noblest of pirate traditions.
I've never been one for tradition. 677 ON THE ENDEAVOUR, Beckett stands at the helm, with th forming behind him. 678 ON THE PEARL, Jack moves toward the wheel, shouts ord
Close haul her! Luff the sails and lay her in irons!
Belay that! We'll be a sitting duck!
Belay that belay that!  679 680 681 682 683 684 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 122. Pintel, Ragetti, Marty, Gibbs, Cotton, all want to protes but Jack cuts each of them off --
Belay it! Stow it! Stow it, stow it belay, belay, stow! ON THE ENDEAVOUR, Beckett sees the Black Pearl, sails luf helpless.
What is he waiting for?

He expects us to honor our agreement. Beckett shrugs -- BELOW HIM, on the gun deck the CANNON PORTS OPEN and the CANNONS emerge -- ON THE BLACK PEARL, its sails flapping, Gibbs watches the move into position against them.
Didn't figure for it to end this way. Always pictured an angry husband.
Reasonable. ON THE ENDEAVOUR, as Beckett sails in for the kill --
Nothing personal, Jack. It's just good business.
UP FROM THE DEPTHS, sailing alongside the Black Pearl. A clean slate grey, no longer encrusted -- ON THE PEARL, Jack grins --
Full canvas!
Aye full canvas! ON THE FLYING DUTCHMAN, WILLIAM TURNER steps out on deck, avenging anger in his eyes, and now in control of the Fly Dutchman -- 679

684  685 686 687 688 689 690 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 123. ON THE BLACK PEARL, Barbossa spins the wheel -- The Dutchman and the Black Pearl split, sail to either si of the Endeavour, trapping it in between. ON THE ENDEAVOUR, Beckett stares in disbelief. Groves, next to him, stares out and sees their doom. To Beckett --
Orders, sir? (waits, nervous) Sir? (waits) Sir -- what do you commmand? Beckett stares across -- at Jack. States Jack Sparrow's question, to himself, with resignation, disgust, amazemen
Who am I? Groves sees that Beckett has lost it -- turns away.
Abandon ship! All hands! Abandon ship! With other crewmen, Groves races for the rail -- vaults o
THE DUTCHMAN AND THE BLACK PEARL OPEN FIRE. And we see th fury of these two ships for the first time.

furious broadside -- Beckett's ship is blown away. ON THE ENDEAVOUR, Beckett steps forward, shots landing al Give him credit, he is fearless in the face of death. A mast falls, Beckett doesn't flinch. The deck gives way 685
Teague raises his fist and SHOUTS. Villenueva grins. Sumb

IN THE CARIBBEAN SEA, Beckett fights to stay above water. East India Company flag floats down, covers him. A brief beneath it, and the flag flattens on the water ON THE BLACK PEARL, the crew cheers. In the midst are MUR MULLROY, trying to their best to blend in.
Aarrgh!
Shiver me timbers!
And mine. That's doesn't sound right to Pintel and Ragetti; they tu toward the (ex-)Marines Jack and Gibbs watch as CAPTAINS of the other Armada ship see the destruction, turn their sails.
They're running!
Aye, they're terrified to take on the combined might of the Dutchman and the Pearl!
I've never seen a retreat from the other side before. Gibbs, you may fling my hat. Gibbs takes Jack's hat and throws it up into the air --
Captain William Turner stands on deck, looking out toward the Black Pearl. Bootstrap steps up beside him.
Orders, sir? Will is surprised.
You're no longer bound to the Dutchman. You're free.  695 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 125.
It's a fine thing. But by my reckoning, I've still got a debt that needs be paid. If you'll have me. Will regards him, a smile fighting to break across his fa He gestures toward the wheel:
On the wheel, then, Mr. Turner
Aye, Captain Turner. Will's gaze is drawn back to Elizabeth; Bootstrap notes i
One day ashore, ten years at sea. It's a steep price to pay for what's been done.
That depends on the one day.
Elizabeth moves to a waiting longboat, past the crew. Bar nods to her.
Your chariot awaits, your highness. Oars are inside.
Mrs. Turner. Jack waits next to the longboat.
(a smile) Jack Sparrow. It never would have worked out between us.
You keep telling yourself that.
Thank you.
Every king needs a queen.  696 697 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 126. They lean together for a kiss, Jack thinks better of it; smiling, she turns away --
Elizabeth sits down on a rock near the water's edge, arms wrapped around her knees. Lost in thought.
Elizabeth. She looks up -- Will is there, standing in the water. She goes out to him, into the water.
Ten years is a long time ... and I don't expect the world to stop turning.
I'll keep it safe. He gazes into her eyes, slowly nods: he has faith. He smi
You've ruined your dress. She blinks back tears. He reaches a hand out for her chee
Will... (remembering the very first meeting) Will Turner.

Captain ... Will Turner. He leans forward to kiss her. Their lips meet, softly. Sh shuts her eyes as the kiss takes her ... CLOSE ON: ELIZABETH'S EYES ... she opens them slowly, see The Flying Dutchman, bound for the sunset. Will is gone. She turns .... REVEAL, on the shore, is the Chest. Elizabeth raises it, holds it close, watches the ship as it gets lost in the sun...
Jack comes down the ramp with Scarlett and Gisele his arm  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 127.
Granted, it tends to list to port and has been known on occasion to frighten young women, but I promise, you will not be disappointed.
Is that it? The Black Pearl?
It's not very big. Jack glances at a small boat.
Please, love. That is a dingy. My vessel is magnificent and fierce and huge-ish and ... gone. Why is it gone? Giselle spots the Black Pearl, far out to sea.
Is that it there?
Yes, there. There it is. Why is it there? (The girls squint) It's much larger up close.
Oh, but Jack, you promised me a ride.
I was to be given a ride first.
What. You?
Better than you.
Not what he said.
I never!
I seen you!
Learn anything?  WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 128.
I learnt you stole my stays.
I never!
You're wearing ‘em! Cat fight ensues. OVER THIS: Jack spots Gibbs, dozing peacefully on the dock
Mr. Gibbs. Is there any particular reason my ship is gone?
Ship? We're on the ship. Jack! The ship is gone!
Girls! Will you PLEASE! Shut it! The ladies freeze, mid-motion tugging each other's hair.

Listen to me. Yes, I lied to you no, I don't love you, of course it makes you look fat, I have never been to Brussels, it is pronounced "egregious," no, I haven't met Pizarro but I love his pies, and all of this pales to insignificance in light of the fact that my ship is gone! Savvy? SLAP! Jack's head is snapped to the side. SLAP! Back the other way. The girls storm off. Gibbs looks at Jack
Take what you can.
Give nothing back. It is a farewell. Gibbs heads off after the ladies.
Tell me, how much do you know about sea turtles? Jack turns to gaze out to sea, gaze fixed on the horizon.
Barbossa enjoys the sun on his face. Opens his eyes -- Pi Ragetti, Cotton, Marty and others are gathered before him  699 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 129. Murtogg and Mullroy attempt to look inconspicuous.
Sir, some of the men don't feel entirely settled about leaving Captain Jack behind --
Again.
Again.
Is that so?
So we were hoping, it would make us feel a whole lot better regardin' our fortunes, if we could see that item you told us about.
On the charts.
With our own eyes.
To help put an ease to our burden of guilt, so to speak.

Ah. Cast your eyes over this, then, mateys ... there's more than one way to live forever. Barbossa pulls out the charts -- the Pirates lean forward Barbossa unrolls them -- there is a large HOLE in the cen where the map has been cut out.

CLOSE ON: the Charts. Jack cautiously rotates the inner circle... revealing a new map. On it: A drawing of a foun Inscribed on the curve: Ponce de Leon. Jack smiles, pulls out his compass, opens it -- and is sh to see: The needle points to almost directly behind him. That can't be right. He looks around -- and finds: a bott of rum, tucked away behind the seat. He picks it up, chec the compass again; whatever he sees makes him smile --  700 WHITE REVISION 7-4-07 130. He leans back, pulls the cork, takes a swig ... begins to hum...
... we're devils and black sheep, really bad eggs ... Drink up me hearties, yo ho... And so Jack Sparrow leaves us the way he arrived, alone, a small boat, sailing into the sunset --
FADE UP ON: Elizabeth, lit by the light of sunset.
We're beggars and blighters, ne'er- do-well cads ...
(just a little behind) . Ne'er-do-well cads ... She beams down. REVEAL: Elizabeth stands barefoot on shor holding the hand of a NINE-YEAR-OLD BOY, who sits atop a very familiar chest.
Drink up, me 'earties, yo ho...
Yes, that's right

Aye, but we're loved by our mums and our dads -- But her SON has broken off after "mums," leaving Elizabet to sing the "and our dads" alone, because he has spotted something on the horizon. Elizabeth looks where he points -- CLOSE ON: ELIZABETH, here eyes searching. She sees someth breaks into a radiant smile as a GREEN FLASH lights up he features --
